page.title: Sporting boycott of South Africa during the apartheid era

revision.comment: Consistent date format. Date formats per [[MOS:DATEFORMAT]] by [[WP:MOSNUMscript|script]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{International opposition to Apartheid}} [[South Africa]] under [[apartheid]] was subjected to a variety of international [[boycott]]s, including on sporting contacts. There was some debate about whether the aim of the boycott was to end segregation in sport, or to end apartheid together.<ref name="Booth2003"> {{cite journal |last=Booth |first=Douglas | authorlink=Doug Booth |year=2003 |title=Hitting Apartheid for Six? The Politics of the South African Sports Boycott |journal=Journal of Contemporary History |volume= 38 |issue= 3 |pages=477–493 |doi=10.1177/0022009403038003008}} </ref>
==United Nations== In 1980, the United Nations began compiling a "Register of Sports Contacts with South Africa".<ref name="nytreg"> {{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE2D61530F936A25757C0A96E948260 |title=U.N. Reports Contacts With South Africa |last=Rogers|first=Thomas|date=15 April 1988 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=23 November 2008}} </ref> This was a list of sportspeople and officials who had participated in events within South Africa.<ref name="nytreg"/> It was compiled mainly from reports in South African newspapers.<ref name="nytreg"/> Being listed did not itself result in any punishment, but was regarded as a moral pressure on athletes.<ref name="nytreg"/> Some sports bodies would discipline athletes based on the register.<ref name="nytreg"/> Athletes could have their names deleted from the register by giving a written undertaking not to return to apartheid South Africa to compete.<ref name="nytreg"/> The register is regarded as having been an effective instrument.<ref name="Booth2003"/><ref name="reddy"> {{cite news |url=http://scnc.ukzn.ac.za/doc/SPORT/SPORTRAM.htm|title=Sports and the liberation struggle: a Tribute to Sam Ramsamy and others who fought apartheid sport |last=Reddy |first=E.S. |publisher=Gandhi-Luthuli documentation centre |accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref><ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,922516,00.html |title=Boycott Blues |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=30 March 1981 |accessdate=23 November 2008}} </ref>
The [[United Nations General Assembly|UN General Assembly]] adopted the '''International Convention against Apartheid in Sports''' on 10 December 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhchr.ch/html/menu3/b/12.htm |title=International Convention Against Apartheid in Sports |date=10 December 1985 |publisher=[[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights]] |accessdate=23 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327030038/http://www.unhchr.ch/html/menu3/b/12.htm |archivedate=27 March 2008 }} </ref>
==Olympic Games== {{main article|Apartheid-era South Africa and the Olympics}} The [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) withdrew its invitation to South Africa to the [[1964 Summer Olympics]] when interior minister [[Jan de Klerk]] insisted the team would not be racially integrated.<ref> {{cite book |last=Booth |first=Douglas |title=The Race Game: Sport and Politics in South Africa |publisher=[[Routledge]] |year=1998 |page=88 |isbn=0-7146-4799-3}} </ref> In [[1968 Summer Olympics|1968]], the IOC was prepared to readmit South Africa after assurances that its team would be multi-racial; but a threatened boycott by African nations and others forestalled this.<ref name="time68">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,900012,00.html|title=Boycotting South Africa|date=8 March 1968|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref> The [[South African Games]] of 1969 and 1973 were intended to allow Olympic-level competition for South Africans against foreign athletes. South Africa was formally expelled from the IOC in 1970.<ref name="mgheyde"> {{cite news |url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2007-01-16-apartheid-the-political-influence-of-sport |title=Apartheid: The political influence of sport |last=auf der Heyde |first=Peter |date=16 January 2007 |work=[[Mail & Guardian]]|accessdate=23 November 2008}} </ref>
In [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976]], African nations demanded that [[New Zealand]] be suspended by the IOC for continued contacts with South Africa, including a tour by the [[New Zealand national rugby union team]]. When the IOC refused, the African teams withdrew from the games.<ref name="AfricaXXIOlympics">{{cite web| title=On This Day 17 July 1976 |publisher=bbc.co.uk |accessdate=17 January 2007 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/july/17/newsid_3555000/3555450.stm | date=17 July 1976}}</ref> This contributed to the [[Gleneagles Agreement]] being adopted by the [[Commonwealth]] in 1977.<ref name="Gleneagles">{{cite web| url=http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/culture/1981-springbok-tour/gleneagles-agreement |title=From Montreal to Gleneagles |accessdate=14 June 2008 |publisher=nzhistory.net.nz |last=Watters |first=Steve}}</ref>
The IOC adopted a declaration against "apartheid in sport" on 21 June 1988, for the total isolation of apartheid sport.<ref name="reddy"/>
==Commonwealth Games== The [[1934 British Empire Games]], originally awarded in 1930 to [[Johannesburg]], was moved to London after the (pre-apartheid) South Africa government refused to allow nonwhite participants.<ref name="Gorman2012">{{cite book|last=Gorman|first=Daniel|title=The Emergence of International Society in the 1920s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b5DlxTDEIaYC&pg=PA170|accessdate=27 May 2013|date=31 July 2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107021136|page=170}}</ref> [[South Africa at the Commonwealth Games|South Africa continued to participate]] in every Games until [[South African Constitution of 1961|it left the Commonwealth in 1961]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecgf.com/countries/tally.asp?countryid=56|title=South Africa - Medals Tally by Games|work=Commonwealth Countries - Results by Games|publisher=Commonwealth Games Federation|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecgf.com/countries/intro.asp?countryid=56&resultsid=&gamesid=|title=South Africa|work=Commonwealth Countries - Introduction|publisher=Commonwealth Games Federation|accessdate=27 May 2013}}</ref> The [[Premiership of Margaret Thatcher|Thatcher government]]'s refusal to enforce the Gleneagles Agreement in the UK led Nigeria to initiate a boycott of the [[1986 Commonwealth Games]] in Edinburgh, from which 32 of 59 eligible teams withdrew.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Downes|first=Aviston D.|year=2002|title=Sport and International Diplomacy: The Case of the Commonwealth Caribbean and the Anti-Apartheid Campaign, 1959–1992|journal=The Sports Historian|volume=22|issue=2|pages=23–45|issn=1351-5462|doi=10.1080/17460260209443382}}; {{cite journal|last=Seidel|first=Gill|year=1988|title=‘We condemn apartheid, BUT …’: a discursive analysis of the European Parliamentary debate on sanctions (July 1986)1|journal=The Sociological Review|volume=36|issue=S1|pages=222–249|issn=0038-0261|doi=10.1111/j.1467-954X.1988.tb03333.x}}; {{cite journal|last=Booth|first=Douglas|year=1995|title=Sports Policy in Australia: Right, Just and Rational?|journal=The Australian Quarterly|volume=67|issue=1|pages=1–10: 3 |issn=0005-0091|doi=10.2307/20635800|jstor=20635800}}</ref>
==NCAA== The [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]], which governs many North American university sports, permitted South Africans to receive [[athletic scholarship]]s and compete in its events.<ref name="Bale1991">{{cite book|last=Bale|first=John|title=The Brawn Drain: Foreign Student-athletes in American Universities|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAT-cFlq0gQC&pg=PA195|accessdate=18 April 2016|date=1991|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=9780252017322|pages=195–6|chapter=Interpreting the Brawn Drain; The South African connection}}</ref> Most such [[student athlete]]s were white; one exception was runner [[Sydney Maree]], who later became a U.S. citizen.<ref name="Bale1991" />
==By sport== The extent of boycotting varied between different sports, in the degree of contact permitted and the severity of punishment of "rebels" who defied the sanctions. This reflected the different political and social composition of each sport's governing [[international federation]] (IF).
===Athletics=== In [[track and field athletics]], a motion to suspend South Africa from the [[IAAF]] was defeated in 1966,<ref>Booth (1998), p.87</ref> but had been passed by 1970.<ref name="booth99"/> [[Zola Budd]]'s time for the [[5000 metres|women's 5,000m]] in January 1984 was not ratified as a [[world records in athletics|world record]] because it was outside the auspices of the IAAF.<ref> {{cite book |last=Bale |first=John |title=Running Cultures: Racing in Time and Space |publisher=[[Routledge]] |year=2004 |pages=141|isbn=0-7146-5535-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3I3PrEgnQZQC&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141}} </ref>
===[[Chess in South Africa|Chess]]=== In the [[19th Chess Olympiad|1970 Chess Olympiad]], a number of players and teams protested against South Africa's inclusion, some withdrawing themselves, and the Albanian team forfeited its match against the South African team. South Africa were expelled from [[FIDE]] while participating in the [[21st Chess Olympiad|1974 Chess Olympiad]], finally returning to international competition in the [[30th Chess Olympiad|1992 Chess Olympiad]].
===Cricket=== Cricket had been organised on racial lines in South Africa from its earliest days with the coloured cricketer [[Krom Hendricks]] excluded from provincial and national teams from the 1890s. However, the cricketing boycott was prompted by the reaction of the South African authorities to the selection of [[Basil D'Oliveira]], a "[[Cape Coloureds|Cape Coloured]]" South African, for the [[England national cricket team]] in 1968;<ref>Booth (1998)</ref> see the [[D'Oliveira affair]]. The 1970 South African tour of England was called off and replaced by a [[Rest of the World cricket team in England in 1970|"Rest of the World" tour]] featuring several South African players. The [[International Cricket Conference]] (ICC) imposed a moratorium on tours in 1970.<ref name="booth99">Booth (1998), p.99</ref> There were [[International cricket in South Africa from 1971 to 1981|several private tours in the 1970s]] and [[South African rebel tours|"rebel" tours in the 1980s]]. Participants in the latter were banned by their national federations upon returning. [[World Series Cricket]], run outside the auspices of the ICC in 1977–79, included South African players in its [[World Series Cricket World XI|"Rest of the World" team]].
===Golf=== In the [[World Cup of Golf|World Cup]], the Greek government banned South Africa from the 1979 competition in [[Athens]]. South Africa competed in the 1980 edition in [[Bogota]]. The prospect of their appearing in the 1981 edition, due to be staged at [[Waterville, County Kerry|Waterville]] in Ireland, caused it to be cancelled. South Africa did not reappear until the post-apartheid era in 1992.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/golf/irish-duo-set-world-cup-record-137692.html |title=Irish duo set World Cup record |last=Gilleece|first=Dermot |date=3 December 2006 |work=[[Irish Independent]] |accessdate=23 November 2008}} </ref>
South African golfers continued to play around the world, including [[PGA Tour]], [[European Tour]], and [[Grand Slam (golf)|Grand Slam]] events. Outside golfers competed freely in [[South African Tour]] events. The [[Sun City Million Dollar Challenge|Million Dollar Challenge]] at the [[Sun City, North West|Sun City resort]] regularly attracted some of the world's top golfers. The [[Official World Golf Ranking]] included South African Tour events in its calculations from its instigation in 1986.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dps.twiihosting.net/wgr/doc/content/archive/1986/owgr01f1986.pdf |title=First issue of Sony rankings |last=Greer |first=Tony |date=6 April 1986 |publisher=[[The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews|Royal and Ancient Golf Club]] |accessdate=23 November 2008 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref>
===Motorsport=== South African [[Jody Scheckter]] was the [[1979 Formula One season|1979 Formula One]] champion. The [[South African Grand Prix|South African Formula One Grand Prix]] and the [[South African motorcycle Grand Prix]] were held in 1985 for the final time until the end of apartheid. Various teams boycotted the [[1985 South African Grand Prix|1985 Formula One race]], some teams in this international motorsport boycotting as part of pressure from their own governments, as part of the mounting pressure against apartheid.
===Rugby union=== {{main article|Rugby union and apartheid}} South Africa remained a member of the [[International Rugby Board]] (IRB) throughout the apartheid era. [[Halt All Racist Tours]] was established in New Zealand in 1969 to oppose continued tours to and from South Africa. Apartheid South Africa's last foreign tour was [[1981 South Africa rugby union tour of New Zealand|to New Zealand in 1981]]. This tour was highly controversial due to the difference of opinions. Though contacts were restricted after the Gleneagles Agreement in 1977, there were controversial tours in 1980 [[1980 British Lions tour to South Africa|by the British Lions]] and [[1980 France rugby union tour of South Africa|by France]], in 1981 [[1981 Ireland rugby union tour of South Africa|by Ireland]], and in 1984 [[1984 England rugby union tour of South Africa|by England]]. In 1986, though a Lions tour was cancelled, South Africans played in all-star matches [[Rest of the World XV|in Cardiff]] and [[Overseas Unions rugby union team|in London]] marking the IRB centenary.<ref>{{cite book|last=Starmer-Smith|first=Nigel|authorlink=Nigel Starmer-Smith|title=Rugby - A Way of Life, An Illustrated History of Rugby|date=1986 |publisher=Lennard Books|isbn=0-7126-2662-X|page=186}}</ref> South Africa was excluded from the first two [[Rugby World Cup]]s, in [[1987 Rugby World Cup|1987]] and [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991]].
===Football=== South Africa was suspended from [[FIFA]] in 1963. [[Stanley Rous]], FIFA's President, went to negotiate its reinstatement. The South African FA proposed entering an all-white team in the [[1966 FIFA World Cup|1966 World Cup]] and an all-black team in the [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970 World Cup]]. This proposal was rejected.<ref name="mgheyde"/>
===Table tennis=== The South African Table Tennis Board (SATTB), a body founded in contravention to the white South African table tennis board, was substituted for the latter by the [[International Table Tennis Federation]]. While the SATTB team was able to participate in the world championships held in [[Stockholm]] in 1957, team members were immediately refused passports by the government. It ruled that no black could compete internationally except through the white sports body.
===Tennis=== The [[South Africa Davis Cup team]] was ejected from the [[1970 Davis Cup]], in part thanks to campaigning by [[Arthur Ashe]]. It was reinstated [[1970 Davis Cup|in 1973]] but placed in the [[1973 Davis Cup Americas Zone|Americas Zone]] instead of the [[1973 Davis Cup Europe Zone|Europe Zone]] where other African countries played. It won the [[1974 Davis Cup]] after [[India Davis Cup team|India]] refused to travel to South Africa for the final. There were protests at its matches in the United States in [[1977 Davis Cup Americas Zone|1977]] and [[1978 Davis Cup Americas Zone|1978]].<ref name="nytimesdeepsouthsslewhester">{{cite news|last1=Amdur|first1=Neil|title=Deep South's Slew Hester: A Canny Tennis Maverick|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/03/20/archives/deep-souths-slew-hester-a-canny-tennis-maverick.html|accessdate=10 July 2017|work=The New York Times|date=20 March 1977}}</ref><ref name="washpostustanochoiceondavis"/><ref name="nytimesusdaviscupteambeats">{{cite news|last1=Amdur|first1=Neil|title=U.S. Davis Cup Team Beats South Africa |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/03/20/archives/us-davis-cup-team-beats-south-africa-us-davis-cup-team-beats-south.html|accessdate=10 July 2017|work=The New York Times|date=20 March 1978}}</ref> In 1977 several countries threatened to withdraw, and in 1978 several did withdraw in protest.<ref>{{cite news |title=U.S. withdraws from Davis Cup |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=edk0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=Kn4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6973,226181&dq=us+withdraws+from+davis+cup&hl=en |work=The Deseret News |date=1 July 1976 |page=24}}</ref> In 1979 South Africa was banned again.<ref>{{cite news |title=South Africa Expelled from Cup Play |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19780417&id=FQ9PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bgIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4837,4807800 |work=Toledo Blade |date=17 April 1978 |page=11}}</ref>
The [[South Africa Fed Cup team|South Africa women's team]] participated in the [[Fed Cup|Federation Cup]] (now Fed Cup) through to [[1977 Federation Cup (tennis)|1977]]. It hosted and won [[1972 Federation Cup (tennis)|the 1972 edition]] in [[Johannesburg]].
[[William Hester]], the president of the [[United States Tennis Association]], decided to let a tournament between the United States and South Africa take place in [[Newport Beach, California]] in April 1977 in spite of backlash from African nations and protesters due to the apartheid regime.<ref name="nytimesdeepsouthsslewhester"/><ref name="washpostustanochoiceondavis">{{cite news|last1=Lorge|first1=Barry|title=USTA: No Choice On Davis Clash With S. Africa |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1978/02/01/usta-no-choice-on-davis-clash-with-s-africa/290ff3e4-d0f7-414b-82d7-65f9b201a735/?utm_term=.eea6683f9029 |accessdate=10 July 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=1 February 1978}}</ref> When protesters ran on the court during the match, [[Tony Trabert]], the U.S. manager, "hit two protestors with a racket" according to ''The Washington Post''.<ref name="washpostustanochoiceondavis"/> Hester also let another Davis Cup tournament take place at [[Vanderbilt University]]'s [[Memorial Gymnasium (Vanderbilt University)|Memorial Gymnasium]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in March 1978 despite protests from civil rights leaders.<ref name="washpostustanochoiceondavis"/> Hester explained, "We do not support or agree with the apartheid policy of the South African government .... But we have entered the draw and, unfortunately, we have to play South Africa - and in the United States."<ref name="washpostustanochoiceondavis"/> Meanwhile, [[Joseph E. Carrico]], the USTA's first vice president at the time and later president, blamed the low attendance on negative stories published by ''[[The Tennessean]]'', even after a reporter was escorted out of the gym by the police.<ref name="nytimesusdaviscupteambeats"/> According to ''The New York Times'', the event included "more police (150) than protesters (40) outside the gym."<ref name="nytimesusdaviscupteambeats"/>
South African players continued to compete on the pro tours; [[Johan Kriek]] and [[Kevin Curren]] reached [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] finals, though both later became naturalised [[Citizenship in the United States|US citizens]].
==Foreign eligibility== Some elite South African sportspeople competed internationally for another country, after becoming eligible through [[naturalization]], length of [[Residency (domicile)|residency]], or other criteria applicable by the relevant IF. Examples include runner [[Zola Budd]], whose UK nationality application was fast-tracked in time for the [[1984 Summer Olympics]];<ref name="ReidAustin2012">{{cite book|editor-last1=Reid|editor-first1=Heather Lynne|editor-last2=Austin|editor-first2=Michael W.|last1=Hardman |first1=Alan R.|last2=Iorwerth|first2=Hywel |title=The Olympics and Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tbIc_qX4vd0C&pg=PA256|accessdate=16 April 2016|year=2012|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|isbn=9780813136486|pages=256–272: 256|chapter=Sport, patriotism, and the Olympic Games}}</ref> and cricketer [[Kepler Wessels]], who acquired Australian eligibility in the 1980s through residency, before returning to South Africa, for whom he played after the end of apartheid.<ref name="Farred2000">{{cite book|last=Farred|first=Grant|title=Midfielder's Moment: Coloured Literature and Culture in Contemporary South Africa|year=2000|publisher=Westview Press|isbn=9780813335148|page=139}}</ref> The 1994 film ''[[Muriel's Wedding]]'' recounts a fictional 1980s Australian's sham marriage to a South African swimmer seeking Olympic eligibility.<ref name="Farred2000" />
==End of apartheid== With the end of apartheid, sports rapidly ended their boycotts and South Africa was readmitted in the [[International sports federations]]. The [[European Community]] announced its member governments' ending of the boycott in June 1991.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE0DA1F3EF933A05755C0A967958260 |author=[[Associated Press]] |title=Europeans Lift South Africa Sports Boycott |date=30 June 1991 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=23 November 2008}} </ref> [[India]], which vehemently opposed South Africa's apartheid policy and was at the forefront of isolating the country internationally at all levels, ended its boycott in 1991 by inviting the [[South Africa national cricket team|South African cricket team]] to the country for [[South African cricket team in India in 1991–92|an ODI series]] and subsequently allowed the [[India national cricket team|Indian cricket team]] to [[Indian cricket team in South Africa in 1992–93|tour South Africa]] for a [[Test cricket|Test]] and [[one day international|ODI]] series in late 1992. The country's hosting and winning of the [[1995 Rugby World Cup]] was a powerful boost to post-apartheid South Africa's return to the international sporting scene.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://update.unu.edu/archive/issue31_2.htm |title=India vs. Pakistan in a tense test of cricket diplomacy |last=Thakur |first=Ramesh |date=May–June 2004 |work=UNU newsletter |publisher=[[United Nations University]] |accessdate=23 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821122824/http://update.unu.edu/archive/issue31_2.htm |archivedate=21 August 2008 }} </ref>
==See also== *[[Sports diplomacy]] *[[Academic boycott of South Africa]] *[[Foreign relations of South Africa during apartheid]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * ''Dancing on Our Bones: New Zealand, South Africa, Rugby and Racism'' by Trevor Richards (Bridget Williams Books, 1999). The author was one of a small group of people who founded Halt All Racist Tours (HART) in Auckland in 1969 and worked for the organisation for many years, serving as chair (1969–1980) and international secretary (1980–1985).
==External links== * {{cite web|publisher=[[African National Congress]] |url=http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/history/boycotts/ |title=Historical documents: Boycotts against Apartheid |year=2001 |accessdate=23 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704130830/http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/history/boycotts/ |archivedate=4 July 2008 }}
{{Political history of South Africa}}

{{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Srednja Bloudkova | nickname = | image = [[Image:Planica-skakalnice1.JPG|270px]] | caption = on right; replaced with HS 62, 80 | constructor(s) = [[Stanko Bloudek]] | location = [[Planica]], [[Slovenia]] | opened = 27 March 1949 | renovated = 1989 | closed = 2007 | demolished = 2012 | k-spot = 90 m | hill size = 100 m | hill record = 110 m (361 ft)
{{flagicon|SLO}} Bine Zupan
(13 Mar 2004) | world cup = 1980, 1981, 1982,
1983, 1984, 1986,
1988, 1989, 1993,
1994 | universiade = 2007 }} '''Srednja Bloudkova''' ({{lang-en|Bloudek's normal hill}}) was a [[ski jumping]] K90 hill located in [[Planica]], Slovenia, that existed between 1949 and 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.osc-planica.si/uploads/file/0EngPlanica10.pdf |title=All comeptitititons and winners in Planica since 1934 |publisher=osc-planica |accessdate=14 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305122001/http://www.osc-planica.si/uploads/file/0EngPlanica10.pdf |archivedate=5 March 2012 |df= }}{{failed verification|date=May 2018}} ==History== The hill was opened in 1949 and constructed by Slovenian [[engineer]] [[Stanko Bloudek]]. The hill has a perfect location and the first original inrun was made of thin steel stick construction. His main assistant at the construction of this hill was Stano Pelan, Slovenian pilot, constructor, bank officer, working supervisor, credited as Planica expert, FIS judge of ski jumping and technical judge delegate. This hill is also known under his name. Winner of first international opening competition on this hill on 27 March 1949 was [[Janez Polda]]. Winner of the last international competition on March 28, 1971 was East German [[Hans-Georg Aschenbach]]. Winner of the first World Cup competition on 21 March 1980 was Austrian [[Hans Millonig]]. Constructors of present hill are brothers [[Vlado Gorišek|Vlado]] and [[Janez Gorišek]]. They reconstructed hill in 1989. In hill axis there was a wooden sculpture of a ski jumper.{{cite web|url=http://www.mss.gov.si/fileadmin/mss.gov.si/pageuploads/razpisi/sport/JR_Planica_vode_1_4_10_P2.pdf|title=Complete environment report for Planica Nordic Centre|accessdate=20 July 2012}} The last World Cup event was on 11 December 1994 with Austrian winner [[Andreas Goldberger]]. In total there was 11 individual World Cup competitions. Last official ski jumping event on this hill was held on 2007 FIS Nordic Junior World Ski Championships replacing [[Tarvisio]], a venue dealing with a lack of snow. Those were also the last ski jumps ever at this hill. As a part of [[Planica Nordic Centre]] renovation, the hill was completely demolished in late 2012. It stands just a few meters away from Stano Pelan Hill and right next to the [[Bloudkova velikanka]]. After they demolished Stano Pelan Hill, they built two completely new medium ski jumping hills at the same place, which are used for training. They are HS 62 and HS 80 size. Those two smaller hills opened in December 2013. == Events == === Nordic combined === {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="background:#fff; {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Stade Armand-Cesari | nickname = Stade de Furiani | image = [[File:Tribune Petrignani (Vue de la Tribune Claude Papi).jpg|300px]]| location = BP 640, [[Furiani]], [[France]] | coordinates = {{coord|42|39|5|N|9|26|34|E|type:landmark_region:FR|display=it}}| broke_ground = | opened = 1932 | closed = |Open demolished = | owner = Communauté d'agglomération de Bastia | operator = | surface = Grass | dimensions = 105m x 68m | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[SC Bastia|Sporting Club de Bastia]] (1932–present)
[[CA Bastia]] | seating_capacity = 33,000 | }} '''Stade Armand-Cesari''', also known as the '''Stade de Furiani''', is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Furiani]], [[France]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches of [[SC Bastia]]. The stadium is able to hold 16,000 people and opened in 1932.http://www.worldstadiums.com/europe/countries/france/corse.shtml It was the venue for the first leg of the [[1978 UEFA Cup Final]], which saw a 0-0 tie between [[SC Bastia]] and the [[Netherlands|Dutch-side]] [[PSV Eindhoven]]. Eventually, PSV won the Final with a 3-0 victory on their home ground [[Philips Stadion]]. The record attendance at the stadium was set on 1 September 2012, when 15,505 people saw Bastia lose against by [[AS Saint-Etienne|St. Etienne]] (0-3) in league matches.[http://www.sc-bastia.net/v4/?page_id=4865 U Stade Armand Cesari], SC Bastia, Retrieved 30 July 2012 (in French).[http://www.sc-bastia.net/v4/?p=16750 Les échos autour de Bastia-Saint-Etienne], [[SC Bastia]], 2 September 2012 (in French). This broke the record set on 26 April 1978, when 15,000 people saw Bastia draw 0-0 against [[PSV Eindhoven]] in the first leg of the [[1978 UEFA Cup Final]]. ==Furiani disaster== [[File:Furiani-stade.jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|Stade de Furiani in 2009.]] {{main|Armand Césari Stadium disaster}} The stadium is mostly known outside Corsica for the '''Furiani disaster''', which took place on 5 May 1992 when one of the four terraces fell, causing the death of 18 people and injuring more than 2,300 others. ===Background=== When they reached the semi-final of the [[Coupe de France 1991-92]], the draw gave Bastia a tie against [[Olympique de Marseille]], the [[Ligue 1|Division 1]] leader at the time. In order to accommodate more fans, the club board decided to create a temporary terrace instead of the old ''Tribune Claude Papi'' which could only take 750 fans. The new capacity of the terrace was 10,000. ===Matchday=== An hour before the start of the match, problems were already noticeable, such as the instability of the structure. At 8:20 p.m., the whole structure collapsed, with supporters and journalists in the wreckage. Every medical option on the island was exhausted. The victims were eventually evacuated to the mainland, including Marseille. [[Bastia - Poretta Airport|Poretta Airport]] was quoted as resembling more of a hospital than an airport that night. ===Aftermath=== On 8 May, an official investigation began in order to find who was responsible. After the disaster, the [[French Football Federation|FFF]] decided - after some hesitation - to cancel the remaining matches in the Cup. On the 12th, the investigators came to the conclusion that there had been a number of rules broken concerning the terrace. All these findings led to the investigation's conclusion "Le soir du 5 mai, il n'y a pas eu de fatalité . (There has been no fate the night of the 5th May)". Ultimately, at the trial a year later, the main protagonists were proved guilty but were only given prison sentences of less than two years. ==Recent history== Since the disaster, the stadium waited a long time to be rebuilt. The ''Tribune Nord'' was rebuilt in 1997, before Bastia could play again in the [[1997–98 UEFA Cup]]. For the 100th anniversary of the club, in 2005, the four terraces were renamed: * North terrace: ''Tribune Claude Papi'' * East terrace: ''Tribune Jojo Petrignani'' * South terrace: ''Tribune Victor Lorenzi'' * West terrace: ''Tribune Pierre Cahuzac'' ==References== ==External links== {{commonscat|Stade Armand-Cesari}} *[http://www.drame-de-furiani.new.fr/ Complete website in french about the disaster ] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111205032955/http://www.petitionfuriani.com/ for 1992] {{SC Bastia}} {{Ligue 2 venues}} [[Category:Football venues in France|Armand Cesari]] [[Category:SC Bastia]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in France]] [[Category:Sports venues in Haute-Corse]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1932]]

[[Trois-Rivières Royals]] ([[Canadian–American League|Can-Am]]) (1941-42, 1946-50)
[[Trois-Rivières Royals]] ([[Quebec Provincial League|QPL]]) (1940) |seating_capacity=4,500 |dimensions= Left field: {{convert|317|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Centre field: {{convert|372|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Right field: {{convert|317|ft|m|abbr=on}}{{cite web|title=Stade Fernand-Bédard|url=http://www.lbeq.com/?corps=info_terrain&P_TERRAIN=10|publisher=[[Ligue de Baseball Junior Élite du Québec]]|accessdate=15 April 2013}} }} '''Stade Stereo+''' (formerly known as '''Stade Fernand-Bédard''') is a [[stadium]] in [[Trois-Rivières]], [[Quebec]], Canada. It is primarily used for [[baseball]] and is the home of the [[Trois-Rivières Aigles (Can-Am)|Trois-Rivières Aigles]] of the [[Canadian American Association of Professional Baseball]]. It was the home of the [[Trois-Rivières Saints]] of the [[Canadian Baseball League]] in 2003. The ballpark has a capacity of 4,500 people and was opened in 1938. It was also the home of Aigles Junior de Trois-Rivières of the [[Ligue de Baseball Junior Élite du Québec]]. The stadium changed its name on 22 June 2016. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Can-Am League Stadiums}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stade Municipal (Trois-Rivieres)}} [[Category:Sports venues in Trois-Rivières]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Quebec]] [[Category:1938 establishments in Quebec]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1938]] {{Quebec-struct-stub}} {{Canada-sports-venue-stub}} {{baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Stade Pierre-Mauroy | nickname = | image = Lille - Saint-Etienne (13-01-2017) 16.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = '''[[UEFA Elite stadium|UEFA]]''' {{rating|4|4}} | location = [[Villeneuve-d'Ascq]], [[Hauts-de-France]] - [[Métropole Européenne de Lille|European Metropolis of Lille]] | coordinates = {{coord|50.6118833|3.13042778|type:landmark|display=inline}} | broke_ground = 2009 | built = 2012 | opened = 17 August 2012 | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Eiffage]] (until 2043) | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]] 282 million
(Hotel, Restaurant cost [[Euro|€]] 42 million, Total complex cost [[Euro|€]] 324 million)| | architect = Pierre Ferret | design-builder = | former_names = Grand Stade Lille Métropole (2012–2013) | tenants = [[Lille OSC]] (2012–present) | seating_capacity = 50,186http://www.stadiumguide.com/grandstadelille/
28,010 (indoor Arena configuration) | dimensions = }} The '''Stade Pierre-Mauroy''' is a multi-use (Arena), [[retractable roof]] [[stadium]] (50,186 seats) in [[Villeneuve-d'Ascq]], [[Lille]] ([[Métropole Européenne de Lille|European Metropolis of Lille]]), [[Hauts-de-France]]; that opened in August 2012. It is located in the Hôtel de Ville quarter of Villeneuve d'Ascq and is the home stadium of [[Lille OSC]]. Initially named '''Grand Stade Lille Métropole''', the stadium was renamed on 21 June 2013, just after the death of the former Mayor of Lille and former [[Prime Minister of France]] [[Pierre Mauroy]].{{cite news|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Ce-sera-le-stade-pierre-mauroy/380279|script-title=Ce sera le stade Pierre Mauroy|title=It will be Stade Pierre Mauroy|date=21 June 2013}} ==History== ===Before the Grand Stade=== In 1975, [[Lille OSC]] began playing at the [[Stade Grimonprez-Jooris]], a 21,128-seat facility. When the club began to play European Competitions, the venue did not match [[UEFA]] standards, prompting the club to play its [[UEFA Champions League]] games at the [[Stade Bollaert-Delelis|Stade Félix-Bollaert]], home of rival [[RC Lens]], in 2001. Plans were soon made to build a new stadium which would match UEFA demands, but the project was postponed and finally cancelled due to struggle with [[preservationist]]s who stated that the location chosen for the new stadium was too close to the 17th Century [[Citadel of Lille|Citadel]]. The club, left without a place to play, moved to the [[Stadium Nord Lille Métropole|Stadium Nord]] which was smaller than Grimonprez-Jooris (18,154 seats) and did not fulfill UEFA demands. This situation forced the team, who had qualified for [[2005–06 UEFA Champions League]], to play at the [[Stade de France]] for its European matches. This solution was abandoned after two young LOSC fans lost their lives when they got hit by an incoming train after a game against [[Olympique Lyonnais]]. ===New administration, new project=== While LOSC was struggling with its stadium problems, the administrative landscape of the Lille area changed. The city was now included in a vast association with its enclosed neighbours, forming the [[Urban Community of Lille Métropole]]. The new administration, now in charge of the whole area, decided to launch a new stadium project. On 5 December 2006, an industrial bid for a 50,000-seat multi-purpose stadium, able to receive sport competitions, cultural shows and hold seminars, was launched.
The following January, three worldwide construction companies answered the call, each one with ambitious projects: * Eiffage: a 50,000-seat capacity multi-purpose stadium, Meeting HQE standards with a [[retractable roof]]. The stadium has also a particularity: it can become a fully functional arena of 30,000 seats in only one hour: the ''Boite à spectacle''. * Bouygues: The project proposed by the company was highly effective in energy saving. The structure was geothermic and most of its power was produced by [[Renewable energy]]. The stadium would have a 50,127-seat capacity. * Vinci: The project proposed by Vinci was the largest of the competition with a 50,921-seat capacity and a retractable roof. It would have been powered by 8000 m² of [[Solar panel]]s On February 2008, Eiffage was selected during a general meeting to build the stadium. The contract was officially signed between the two parties on October of the same year. Eiffage was given 45 months to complete the project ===Stadium construction=== On 10 July 2009, Eiffage received the building permit and authorisation to start preparatory works for the construction at the ''Borne de l'Espoir'' location in [[Villeneuve-d'Ascq]]. In December 2009, the final two cities of the Lille Métropole who had yet to sign the building permit joined the project and gave their authorisation. In February 2010, France officially became a candidate to organize the [[UEFA Euro 2016]]. The Grand Stade become the symbol of the candidature, boosting its public support.http://www.lagazettedescommunes.com/4747/nord-pas-de-calais-le-grand-stade-de-lille-locomotive-de-la-candidature-a-leuro-2016/ In March 2010, construction of access infrastructure (Subway, Highway, parking lots) began followed one week after by the beginning of the construction of the arena itself. On 28 May 2010, France was officially chosen to organize the Euro 2016. [[Martine Aubry]], who succeeded [[Pierre Mauroy]] at the head of LCMU and a big supporter of LOSC and the Grand Stade, expressed her wish to see the Grand Stade given a prominent amount of competition for the upcoming competition.http://www.leparisien.fr/lille-59000/euro-2016-martine-aubry-veut-huit-matches-au-grand-stade-27-09-2010-1085064.php Construction accelerated, with the first brick laid by the Eiffage CEO in September 2010. In 2011, the structure supporting the roof was put in place and constructions of the northern stand was completed by the end of that year. In 2012, the retractable roof, constructed in one piece, was successfully put in place in one day. Despite some legal delays, the stadium was delivered on schedule during the summer of 2012, in time for the 2012–13 LOSC season. ==The stadium== ===Cost and financing=== The total cost of the Eiffage project was €618 million, including €282 million for the stadium, €42 million for additional development such as parking, hotels, and restaurants, and €96 million to ensure seismic standards were met. This latter requirement was introduced in 2011, following a new law passed in the wake of the massive [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Japan earthquake and tsunami]]. The cost was spread between the city of Lille (€24.7 million annually for 31 years), the LOSC (€7.5 million annually) and the [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais]] regional council (€45 million). The cost of the project spurred considerable controversy. On one hand, [[Martine Aubry]] and her First Deputy [[Pierre de Saintignon]], in charge of the project, highlighted the Grand Stade as "a splendid ambassador of the technologies of our region, and a great tool of attractivity". On the other hand, opponents pointed to a lack of long term viability, since part of the public investments were bound to sporting events, whose results are of random nature. This could lead to some new kind of toxic loans.{{cite news| journal= L'Express|url=http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/sport/football/le-vrai-cout-du-grand-stade-de-lille_1177507.html|script-title=Le vrai coût du grand stade de Lille|title=The true price of the Grand Stade of Lille|author=Jacques Trentesaux|date=23 October 2012}} ===Multiple floor features=== [[File:Mauroy Stadium Eurobasket 2015.JPG|thumb|right|Stade Pierre-Mauroy during the [[FIBA EuroBasket 2015]]]] Stade Pierre-Mauroy has two floors or main levels. The full stadium level or ''Grand Stade'' reaches a height of 31 m (101 feet) and has a total capacity of 50,186 seats including 4,965 business seats, 1,842 luxury-box seats, 448 protocol seats and 326 reserved for the press. The stadium has also a peculiarity: half of the ''Grand Stade'' field is situated on hydraulics lift and massive tracks that raise and slide it above the other half of the field in three hours. This creates a second lower level floor plan and surrounding seats called ''Boîte à Spectacles'', where basketball, tennis or music shows can take place. The ''Boîte à Spectacles'' can be configured to have a variable capacity, from 6,900 to 30,000 seats. In November 2014, it hosted the [[2014 Davis Cup]] finals between France and Switzerland, where an attendance record was broken for the highest-ever officially sanctioned competition tennis match. In [[2017 Davis Cup|2017]] it hosted the Davis Cup final again. [[File:Pierre Mauroy Stadium Tennis.jpg|thumb|right|Stade Pierre-Mauroy during the 2017 Davis Cup final]] In addition, Stade Pierre-Mauroy has a retractable roof which opens and shuts in 15 minutes. The stadium is also recognised as a [[Haute Qualité Environnementale|HQE]] Building with solar panels and two windmills to provide as electrical supply. The stadium is fully accessible by metro stations and road and includes 7,000 parking spaces. ===Tenants=== The Grand Stade received a five-star UEFA ranking. It is expected to significantly increase the revenue streams of [[Lille OSC]], its tenant club. The stadium hosted its first rugby union Test match on 17 November 2012 during the [[2012 end-of-year rugby union tests|2012 Autumn Internationals]], when [[France national rugby union team|France]] defeated [[Argentina national rugby union team|Argentina]] 39–22.http://www.espnscrum.com/argentina-tour-2012/rugby/match/154936.html ==EuroBasket 2015 matches== The knock-out phase of [[EuroBasket 2015]] was held at the Stade Pierre-Mauroy from 12–20 September 2015, including the [[EuroBasket 2015 Final|Final]]. {{About|the 2009 feature film about an American football player|other films of the same name|The Blind Side (disambiguation){{!}}The Blind Side}} {{Infobox film | name = The Blind | image = Blind side poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | alt = A relatively small blonde women stands beside a large football player, facing away from the viewer. | director = [[John Lee Hancock]] | producer = {{ubl|[[Broderick Johnson]]|[[Andrew Kosove]]|Gil Netter}} | screenplay = John Lee Hancock | based on = {{Based on|''[[The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game]]''|[[Michael Lewis]]}} | starring = {{Plain list| * [[Sandra Bullock]] * [[Tim McGraw]] * [[Quinton Aaron]] * [[Jae Head]] * [[Lily Collins]] * [[Ray McKinnon (actor)|Ray McKinnon]] * [[Kathy Bates]] }} | music = [[Carter Burwell]] | cinematography = Alar Kivilo | editing = [[Mark Livolsi]] | studio = [[Alcon Entertainment]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros. Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2009|11|20}} | runtime = 126 minutes<ref name="www.boxofficemojo.com"/> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $29 million<ref name="www.boxofficemojo.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=blindside.htm|title=The Blind Side Box Office|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=June 5, 2010}}</ref> | gross = $309.2 million<ref name="www.boxofficemojo.com" /> }} '''''The Blind Side''''' is a 2009 American [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[Sports film|sports]] [[drama film]] written and directed by [[John Lee Hancock]], based on the 2006 book ''[[The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game]]'' by [[Michael Lewis]].<ref name="variety">{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118001814.html |author=Dave McNary|title=Kathy Bates to star in 'Blind Side'|work=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''|date=March 27, 2009|accessdate=June 7, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0878804/ | title = The Blind Side (2009) | publisher = [[Internet Movie Database]] | date = April 22, 2009 | accessdate = May 8, 2009 }}</ref> The storyline features [[Michael Oher]], an [[offensive lineman]] who was drafted by the [[Baltimore Ravens]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). The film follows Oher from his impoverished upbringing, through his years at Wingate Christian School (a fictional representation of [[Briarcrest Christian School]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]]),<ref>[http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2009/nov/24/briarcrest-opted-out-of-blind-side-feature-role/ Briarcrest opted out of feature role in 'The Blind Side'] from CommercialAppeal.com</ref> his adoption by [[Sean Tuohy|Sean]] and [[Leigh Anne Tuohy]], to his position as one of the most highly coveted prospects in [[college football]], then finally becoming a first-round pick of the Ravens.
[[Quinton Aaron]] stars as Michael Oher, alongside [[Sandra Bullock]] as Leigh Anne Tuohy, [[Tim McGraw]] as Sean Tuohy, and [[Kathy Bates]] as Miss Sue, Oher's tutor.<ref name=variety/> The film also features appearances by several current and former [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] coaches, including [[Houston Nutt]], [[Ed Orgeron]], [[Nick Saban]], [[Lou Holtz]], [[Tommy Tuberville]], and [[Phillip Fulmer]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/columns/story?columnist=schlabach_mark&id=4277330 | title = Prominent coaches turn actors for film | author = Schlabach, Mark | publisher = [[ESPN]] | date = June 29, 2009 | accessdate = July 1, 2009 }}</ref>
''The Blind Side'' grossed over $300 million. Bullock went on to win the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]], as well as the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress]] and the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role]]. The film also received an [[Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], which was considered a surprise for the producers and led the Academy to change their requirements for Best Picture nominations.
==Plot== <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, the plot summary should be 400 to 700 words. --> The film opens with seventeen-year-old Michael ("Big Mike") Oher talking to an [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] investigator. Then a [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]] ensues.
Michael has been in foster care with different families in Memphis, Tennessee, due to his mother's drug addiction. Every time he is placed in a new home, he runs away. His friend's father, on whose couch Mike had been sleeping, asks Burt Cotton, the coach of Wingate Christian School, to help enroll his son and Mike. Impressed by Mike's size and athleticism, Cotton gets him admitted despite his poor academic record. Later, Michael is befriended by a younger student named Sean Jr. ("SJ"). SJ's mother, Leigh Anne Tuohy, is a strong-minded interior designer and the wife of wealthy businessman Sean Tuohy.
The school staff tell Michael that his father has died, apparently due to an accident. Later, Leigh Anne and Sean watch their daughter Collins playing volleyball. After the game, Sean notices Michael picking up leftover food on the bleachers.
One night, Leigh Anne notices Michael walking alone on the moist road, shivering in the cold without adequate clothing. When she learns that he plans to spend the night huddled outside the closed school gym, Leigh Anne offers to let him sleep on the couch in the Tuohy home.
The next morning, Leigh Anne notices that Michael has left. Seeing him walking away, she asks him to spend the Thanksgiving holiday with her family. Slowly, Michael becomes a member of the family. Later, Leigh Anne drives Michael to his mother's house. He sees an eviction notice posted on the door, and his mother is gone.
Leigh Anne's friends wonder what she is doing; they suggest that Collins might not be safe around Michael, but Leigh Anne rebukes them. She later asks Collins how she feels about it. Collins replies that they cannot just throw Michael out. When Leigh Anne seeks to become Michael's legal guardian, she learns he was taken from his drug-addict mother when he was seven and that no one knows her whereabouts. She is also told that, although he scored poorly in a career aptitude test, he was ranked in the 98th percentile in "protective instincts". When Michael appears to be hesitant to use his strength and size while learning to play football, Leigh Anne tells him, as an offensive lineman, he must protect his quarterback. From that moment, Michael improves drastically, well enough to play at the college level. However, to do that, he must meet the minimum [[Grading (education)|grade point average]] to get in so the Tuohys hire a private tutor for him, the outspoken and kind Miss Sue.
Leigh Anne has a face-to-face conversation with Michael's mother about adopting him. Although she seems unresponsive in the beginning, the mother finally wishes Michael the best.
Michael is heavily recruited by many prestigious schools. SJ talks to coaches and negotiates on Michael's behalf – and his own. When Michael gets his grades high enough, he decides to attend Ole Miss, where Sean had played and Leigh Anne had been a cheerleader. That causes NCAA investigator Granger to look into the matter to determine if the Tuohys took him in and unduly influenced him just so he would play for their [[alma mater]].
Michael runs away before the interview is over and confronts Leigh Anne about her motives for taking him in. He then proceeds to find his biological mother in Hurt Village. A gang leader welcomes him back, offers him a beer, and makes sexually offensive insinuations about Leigh Anne and Collins. When the gang leader threatens to go after them, Michael battles with him and other thugs. After thinking things over and questioning Leigh Anne, Michael tells Granger he chose Ole Miss because "it's where my family goes to school". Michael is accepted into college and says his farewells to the Tuohy family.
The film ends with information about and photos of the real Tuohy family and Michael Oher, who went on to play in the [[National Football League]]. He was drafted by the [[Baltimore Ravens]] in the first round of the [[2009 NFL Draft]].
==Cast== [[File:Sandra Bullock at the 2010 SAG Awards.jpg|thumb|220px|Sandra Bullock in 2010 after receiving the SAG award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role]] * [[Quinton Aaron]] as [[Michael Oher|Michael "Big Mike" Oher]] * [[Sandra Bullock]] as [[Leigh Anne Tuohy]] * [[Tim McGraw]] as [[Sean Tuohy]] * [[Jae Head]] as Sean "S.J." Tuohy, Jr. * [[Lily Collins]] as Collins Tuohy * [[Kathy Bates]] as Miss Sue * [[Ray McKinnon (actor)|Ray McKinnon]] as [[Hugh Freeze|Coach Burt Cotton]] * [[Kim Dickens]] as Mrs. Boswell * [[Adriane Lenox]] as Denise Oher * [[Eaddy Mays]] as Elaine * [[IronE Singleton|Robert "IronE" Singleton]] as Alton
===Coaches playing themselves=== * [[Tommy Tuberville]], the coach of [[Auburn Tigers football|Auburn]] * [[Nick Saban]], the coach of [[LSU Tigers|Louisiana State]] * [[Lou Holtz]], the coach of [[South Carolina Gamecocks football|South Carolina]] * [[Phillip Fulmer]], the coach of [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee]] * [[Houston Nutt]], the coach of [[Arkansas Razorbacks football|Arkansas]] * [[Ed Orgeron]], the coach of [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]]
==Production== ''The Blind Side'' was produced by [[Alcon Entertainment]] and released by [[Warner Bros.]] The film's production budget was $29 million.<ref name="www.boxofficemojo.com" /> Filming for the school scenes took place at [[Atlanta International School]] and [[The Westminster Schools]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], and it features many of their students as extras. The film premiered on November 17 in [[New York City]] and New Orleans and opened in theaters on November 20 in the rest of the United States and in Canada.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0878804/releaseinfo The Blind Side – Release dates]</ref>
Academy Award winner [[Julia Roberts]] was originally offered Bullock's role, but turned it down.<ref>{{cite news|last=Abramowitz |first=Rachel |url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/env-et-globesfilm16-2009dec16,0,5476124.story |title=A Bonanza Year for Sandra Bullock |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|date=December 16, 2009 |accessdate=March 8, 2010}}</ref> Bullock initially turned down the starring role three times due to discomfort with portraying a devout [[Christian]]. By her own account, Bullock felt she couldn't objectively represent such a person's beliefs on screen.<ref>{{cite web|last=Swartzendruber |first=Jay |url=http://www.crosswalk.com/movies/11616855/ |title=Believers Walk the Talk in The Blind Side |publisher=Crosswalk.com |date=November 17, 2010 |accessdate=March 8, 2010}}</ref> But after a visit with the real Leigh Anne Tuohy, Bullock not only won the role, but also took a pay cut and agreed to receive a percentage of the profits instead.<ref>[http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/11/22/sandra-bullock-scores-touchdown-at-box-office/ "Sandra Bullock scores touchdown at box office"] on Reuters.com {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512223236/http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2009/11/22/sandra-bullock-scores-touchdown-at-box-office/ |date=2014-05-12 }}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''The Blind Side'' opened in 3,110 theaters on its opening weekend, the weekend of November 20, 2009. It grossed a strong $34,510,000 in its opening weekend, the second highest gross of that weekend, behind ''[[The Twilight Saga: New Moon]]''. It was the highest-grossing opening weekend of [[Sandra Bullock]]'s career. The per-theater average for ''The Blind Side''{{'}}s opening weekend was $11,096.<ref>[http://boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2009&wknd=47&p=.htm Weekend Box Office Results for November 20–22, 2009] from [[Box Office Mojo]]</ref> In its opening weekend, the movie already earned more than its $29 million production budget. It proved to have remarkable staying power, taking in an additional $9.5 million, bringing its gross to $60,125,000 by the weekend of November 27, 2009.<ref>[http://boxofficemojo.com/daily/chart/?sortdate=2009-11-26&p=.htm Daily Box Office for Thursday, November 26, 2009] from [[Box Office Mojo]]</ref> The movie enjoyed [[second weekend in box office performance|a rare greater success]] for the second weekend than it did in its opening weekend, taking in an estimated $40 million, an increase of 18 percent, from November 27 to November 29, 2009, coming in second to ''New Moon'' once again, bringing its gross to $100,250,000.<ref name="www.boxofficemojo.com" />
In its third weekend, the movie continued its trend of rare feats by moving up to the number one position with $20.4 million in sales after spending the previous two weekends in second place for a total gross of $128.8 million, due to strong word-of-mouth.<ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i6b990557a161eea8309834f940d9757c "'Blind Side' tops 'New Moon' at box office"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091212095101/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i6b990557a161eea8309834f940d9757c |date=2009-12-12 }} from ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''</ref> In its fourth weekend, it moved down to second place, dropping a slim 23% with an estimated $15.5 million for a total of $150.2 million in the United States and Canada as of December 13, 2009.<ref>[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/ Weekend Box Office Results for January 8–10, 2010] from [[Box Office Mojo]]</ref> The film hit $200 million domestically on January 1, 2010, marking the first time a movie marketed with a sole actress' name above the title (Bullock's) has crossed the $200 million mark.<ref>[http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/01/02/avatar-passes-300-million/ "'Avatar' passes $300 million mark on Friday, and Sandra Bullock makes box-office history"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120529193407/http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/01/02/avatar-passes-300-million/ |date=2012-05-29 }} from ''[[Hollywood Insider]]''</ref> ''The Blind Side'' has also become the highest grossing football movie and sports drama of all time domestically <ref>[http://boxofficemojo.com/genres/chart/?id=football.htm Sports – Football Movies at the Box Office]. [[Box Office Mojo]]. Retrieved on January 23, 2011</ref><ref>[http://boxofficemojo.com/genres/chart/?id=sportsdrama.htm Sports Drama Movies at the Box Office]. [[Box Office Mojo]]. Retrieved on January 23, 2011</ref> unadjusted for ticket inflation.<ref>[http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2634&p=.htm Weekend Report: ‘Avatar’ Rocks New Year’s]. [[Box Office Mojo]] (January 4, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2011.</ref> ''The Blind Side'' ended its domestic theatrical run on June 4, 2010 (nearly 7 months after it opened), earning a total of $255,959,475.<ref>[http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2805&p=.htm End-of-Run Report: 'Blind Side,' 'Crazy Heart,' 'Runaways' Close]. [[Box Office Mojo]] (June 6, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2011</ref> In the [[UK]] and [[Ireland]], ''The Blind Side'' was released on March 26, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/b/The-Blind-Side/index-9097905.html|title=The Blind Side|work=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=July 23, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315060615/http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/b/The-Blind-Side/index-9097905.html|archive-date=2010-03-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> It was the third biggest release of that weekend behind ''[[Nanny McPhee and the Big Bang]]'' and [[Tim Burton]]'s ''[[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|Alice in Wonderland]]''.<ref name="Gant">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2010/mar/30/uk-box-office-nanny-mcphee|title=Nanny McPhee sends Alice in Wonderland to the naughty step at the UK box office|last=Gant|first=Charles|work=Film|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=July 23, 2010 | location=London | date=March 30, 2010}}</ref>
===Critical response=== The film received moderately positive reviews, with critics praising Sandra Bullock's performance. Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a rating of 69%, based on 196 reviews, with a [[weighted mean|rating average]] of 6.1/10. The site's general consensus reads, "It might strike some viewers as a little too pat, but ''The Blind Side'' has the benefit of strong source material and a strong performance from Sandra Bullock."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1212694_blind_side | title=The Blind Side (2009) | work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher = [[Flixster]] | accessdate = December 14, 2009 }}</ref> [[Metacritic]], which assigned a [[standard score|normalized]] score of 53 out of 100, based on reviews from 29 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/blindside | title = The Blind Side: Reviews (2009) | publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] | work = [[Metacritic]] | accessdate = December 26, 2009 }}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film a rare "A+" grade.<ref>http://www.thewrap.com/movies-you-loved-or-hated-films-got-or-f-cinemascores-photos-90331/10/</ref>
{{Expand section|date=September 2017}}<!-- comments from individual critics needed, not just an overview -->
====Race controversy====
''The Blind Side'' has been criticized as presenting a [[White savior narrative in film|white savior narrative]] in which Oher, an African-American male, is unable to overcome poverty and personal failure without the guidance of adoptive, white mother Tuohy. For example, Jeffrey Montez de Oca of the [[University of Colorado]] writes that in ''The Blind Side''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s portrayal of [[adoption]], "charity operates as a signifying act of whiteness that obscures the social relations of domination that not only make charity possible but also creates an urban underclass in need of charity."<ref>Montez de Oca, J. (2012). White Domestic Goddess on a Postmodern Plantation: Charity and Commodity Racism in The Blind Side. Sociology Of Sport Journal, 29(2), 131–150.</ref> Melissa Anderson of the ''[[Dallas Observer]]'' argues that the "mute, docile" portrayal of Oher effectively endorses the [[Uncle Tom]] stereotype of African-American submission to white authority.<ref>Melissa Anderson, [http://www.dallasobserver.com/2009-11-19/film/the-blind-side-what-would-black-people-do-without-nice-white-folks/ ''The Blind Side'': What Would Black People Do Without Nice White Folks?], 19 November 2009.</ref>
Oher was later quoted as saying that "It's a great story. It seems like they helped me to get to this point. They're my family and without them I wouldn't be here," and "They taught me a lot of things, showed me a lot of different things. It shows that if you help somebody and give somebody a chance and don't judge people, look where they can get to."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/us-sports/super-bowl-50-the-blind-side-michael-oher-feels-wanted-at-carolina-panthers-ahead-of-showpiece-20160128-gmgmep.html|title=Super Bowl 50: 'The Blind Side' Michael Oher feels wanted at Carolina Panthers|last=Person|first=Joseph|date=2016-01-29|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Awards and nominations=== {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} ''The Blind Side'' has earned numerous awards and nominations for the lead performance of the film's star, Sandra Bullock.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Association ! Category ! Nominee ! Result |- |rowspan=2|[[82nd Academy Awards|Academy Awards]] |[[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] |Gil Netter, [[Andrew Kosove]] and [[Broderick Johnson]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress in a Leading Role]] |rowspan=8|[[Sandra Bullock]] |{{Won}} |- |[[15th Critics' Choice Awards|Critics’ Choice Awards]] |[[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] |{{Won}} |- |[[67th Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]] |[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama]] |{{Won}} |- |[[2010 Kids' Choice Awards|Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards]] |[[2010 Kids' Choice Awards|Favorite Movie Actress]] |{{Nom}} |- |[[16th Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Awards]] |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role|Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role]] |{{Won}} |- |[[36th People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Awards]] |[[36th People's Choice Awards|Favorite Movie Actress]] |{{Won}} |- |[[Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association Awards 2009|Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association]] |[[Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association Awards 2009|Best Actress]] |{{Nom}} |- |rowspan=3|[[Teen Choice Awards 2010|Teen Choice Awards]] |[[2010 Teen Choice Awards#Movie|Movie Actress – Drama]] |{{won}} |- |[[2010 Teen Choice Awards#Movie|Breakout Male Actor]] |[[Quinton Aaron]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie - Drama|Favorite Drama Movie]] |rowspan=2|''The Blind Side'' |{{won}} |- |[[ESPY Awards]] |[[Best Sports Movie ESPY Award|Best Sports Movie]] |{{Won}} |- |[[Movieguide Awards]] |Best Movie for Mature Audiences<br>Epiphany Prize for Inspiring Movies |''The Blind Side'' |{{Won}}<ref>{{cite web|title=2010 Movieguide Awards Winners|url=https://movieguideawards.com/2010-movieguide-awards-winners/|website=Movieguide|accessdate=29 June 2017|date=1 February 2010}}</ref> |}
====Best Picture nomination====
The nomination of ''The Blind Side'' for Best Picture was considered a surprise, even to its producers.<ref name="NYT021010">Michael Cieply and Paula Schwartz, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/06/movies/awardsseason/06blind.html ‘Blind Side’ Finds a Path to the Oscars by Running Up the Middle], ''The New York Times'', February 10, 2010, accessed February 4, 2014.</ref> In an attempt to revitalize interest surrounding the awards, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had upped the number of Best Picture nominees from a mandatory number of five to ten in time for the [[82nd Academy Awards]], the year ''The Blind Side'' was nominated.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2009/20090624.html |title=82nd Academy Awards to Feature 10 Best Picture Nominees |work=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|publisher=AMPAS |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=February 4, 2014| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100408200952/http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2009/20090624.html| archivedate= April 8, 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> However, in 2011, the Academy changed the policy, stating that the Best Picture category would feature between five and ten nominees depending on voting results, as opposed to a set number of nominees.<ref>{{cite news | title=Academy Builds Surprise Into Best Picture Rules | url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2011/20110614a.html | work=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] | publisher=AMPAS | date=June 14, 2011 | accessdate=February 4, 2014| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110623090310/http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2011/20110614a.html| archivedate= June 23, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=May 2015}} The change was interpreted as a response to films like ''The Blind Side'' being nominated for Best Picture to fill up the set number of spots.<ref name="ew061511">David Karger, [http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/06/15/oscar-best-picture-rules/ The Academy's new Best Picture rule: How it will change the prediction period], ''Entertainment Weekly'', June 15, 2011, accessed February 4, 2014.</ref><ref name="LAT061611">Nicole Sperling and Amy Kaufman, [http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jun/16/entertainment/la-et-academy-changes-20110616 Oscars change rule for best-picture race], ''Los Angeles Times'', June 16, 2011, accessed February 4, 2014.</ref>
==Soundtrack== {{Anchor|Music}} The movie features 23 songs by artists including [[Les Paul]], [[Young MC]], [[Lucy Woodward]], [[The Books]], [[Canned Heat]], [[Five for Fighting]], and the film's co-star [[Tim McGraw]].<ref>[http://www.what-song.com/movie/title.php?Title=Blind%20Side,%20The Blind Side, The [2009] Soundtrack @ what-song]. What-song.com. Retrieved on January 23, 2011</ref> However, while the score soundtrack by [[Carter Burwell]] was released on CD, none of the featured songs were included.
==Home media== ''The Blind Side'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray on March 23, 2010. ''The Blind Side'' was available exclusively for rental from [[Blockbuster LLC|Blockbuster]] for 28 days.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2010/03/15/daily53.html | first=Kerri | last=Panchuk | title=Blockbuster CEO: The movie's not over yet | date=March 19, 2010}}</ref>
[[Redbox]] and [[Netflix]] customers had to wait 28 days before they were able to rent the movie.<ref>[http://netflix.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=43&item=342 Warner Bros. Home Entertainment And Netflix Announce New Agreements Covering Availability Of Dvds, Blu-Ray And Streaming Content] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308065403/http://netflix.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=43&item=342 |date=2012-03-08 }}. Netflix.mediaroom.com (January 6, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2011</ref><ref name="redbox">[http://redboxpressroom.com/releases/PressRelease_WarnerBros_021610.html redbox press room] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100530194502/http://redboxpressroom.com/releases/PressRelease_WarnerBros_021610.html |date=2010-05-30 }}. redbox press room (February 16, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2011</ref> This stems from the settlement of a lawsuit brought by Redbox against Warner Home Video, who, in an attempt to boost DVD sales, refused to sell wholesale titles to Redbox. On August 19, 2009 Redbox sued Warner Home Video<ref>[http://redboxpressroom.com/releases/PressRelease_Warner_081909.html redbox press room] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329044803/http://redboxpressroom.com/releases/PressRelease_Warner_081909.html |date=2010-03-29 }}. redbox press room (August 19, 2009). Retrieved on January 23, 2011</ref> to continue purchasing DVD titles at wholesale prices. On February 16, 2010, Redbox settled the lawsuit<ref name="redbox" /> and agreed to a 28-day window past the street date.
As of July 9, 2013, units sold for the DVD stand at more than 8.4 million copies and has grossed a further $107,962,159 adding to its total gross.<ref>[http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2009/BLDSD-DVD.php The Blind Side – DVD Sales]. The Numbers. Retrieved on July 9, 2013</ref>

The team play their home matches in the [[Bornova Ice Sports Hall]]. ==Achievements== The team was runner-up in the seasons 2012–13, 2014–15 and 2015–16.
